guide.title: Gentoo Kernel Project
guide.subtitle: Main Page (WiP)
guide.abstract: The Gentoo Kernel project has the goal of bringing a consistent kernel featureset across all architectures supported by Gentoo Linux.

body.p: More and more Gentoo users are emerging from unknown locations. They want to have a good and stable experience with their favorite distribution, Gentoo Linux. The kernel they use is an important part of their experience. Because Gentoo Linux wants the best for it's users, Gentoo Linux provides them with several possible kernel tree's, each with their own expertise and features.

In order to provide a rich choice of high quality kerneltrees Gentoo Linux must test and combine several kernelpatches before they can offer finished ebuilds to the users. This is where the Gentoo Kernel Project comes into play.

The Gentoo Kernel Project tries to give the best possible kernel featuresets across all platforms. By having a clearly set management team with published objectives, established timelines, and project accountability, the project will help bring the end-user experience for our kernels to even higher levels.
Currenly the project provides the following featuresets, each one of them being a seperate subproject for the Gentoo Kernel Project.

tr.ti: Feature-rich, high-performance Gentoo Kernel for x86 processors.
Gentoo Kernel created for stability, supporting x86 processors.
Developmental Gentoo Kernel which moves it's code base into gentoo-sources
Gentoo Kernel supporting PPC processors, including ppc-sources-benh, ppc-sources-crypto, ppc-sources-dev
Gentoo Kernel supporting x86 processors and XFS filesystem. Used by the Gentoo LiveCD.

body.p: Gentoo provides ebuilds for other linux kernels such as vanilla-sources, ac-sources, ck-sources, etc,... While not official supported and provided as a courtesy to our user base, info on such kernels can be found here.
The following Gentoo Developers are working on one or more Gentoo Kernel Project specific items. Each of them can be reached individually using nickname@gentoo.org.

tr.ti: Strategic Manager, Operational Manager, gentoo-sources/pfeifer-sources lead

body.p: Each subproject must make sure that the kernel ebuilds they provide adhere to the following quality demands:

ul.li: Each kernel ebuild must compile and work on as many systems as possible before committing to the Portage tree (even if package.mask is used).
Each kernel ebuild should not have Gentoo-specific bugs on http://bugs.gentoo.org/ in the last 1-2 weeks after being released before moving from ~ARCH to ARCH
Every kernel-tree released by the Gentoo Kernel Project must have a clear description on what it contains (patches) and what philosophy is behind it's existence

Any kernel feature that has a userspace utility, must have the appropriate userspace utility ready for inclusion in portage before the kernel is released (ie. evms2, freeswan, USAGI,...). The 2 should be released @ the same time.

body.p: As kernels continue to develop in a vast pace, the Gentoo Kernel Project must make sure that it keeps track of all kerneltrees it provides so that our users will receive the latest and greatest kerneltrees in a timely fashion without losing the quality they are accustomed to.
The Gentoo Kernel Project cannot guarantee that the provided kernel ebuilds work on your system, but it will bring a Best Effort to help every user with problems concerning the kernel ebuilds.

Certain ebuilds are however not officially supported: development-sources and mm-sources are both based on the Linux 2.5 development tree and should be seen as unstable. These kernels are not for the faint of heart, and are only provided for de Gentoo users that know what they are getting into.

As with most projects, the Gentoo Kernel Project and it's subprojects use a roadmap to inform the users and developers about current development items, near-future integrations, seeable future enhancements and far future proposals.
You can view our roadmap here.
In order for our users to be able to pick the best kernel ebuild we provide them with a Kernel Guide in which all available kernel ebuilds are listed and described.
